title: 114_s2669
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ensuring Removal of Terminated Providers from Medicaid and CHIP Act." It aims to increase oversight of termination of Medicaid providers. The "Ensuring Removal of Terminated Providers from Medicaid and CHIP Act" aims to increase oversight and reporting requirements for provider terminations under the State plan. Starting July 1, 2018, states must report terminations for specified reasons to the Secretary. The State must submit provider details within 21 business days of termination, including name, provider type, specialty, personal information, reason for termination. The termination process requires submission of provider details within 21 days, including reason for termination, notice copy, effective date, and additional information as needed by the Secretary. The effective date is defined as the later of the specified termination date or the date when all appeal rights expire. The termination process for providers requires submission of details within 21 days, including the reason for termination and effective date. Managed care contracts must include a provision for terminating providers from participation by July 1, 2018. The termination process for providers under titles XVIII and XXI involves a notification database for tracking terminations, with a review by the Secretary within 21 business days. The termination process for providers under titles XVIII and XXI involves a notification database for tracking terminations, with a review by the Secretary within 21 business days. If the Secretary deems necessary, the termination can be included in a database developed under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. No federal funds will be provided for items and services from terminated providers under the Social Security Act. The State plan termination process involves a notification database for tracking terminations, with a review by the Secretary within 21 business days. No payment will be made to a State for services provided by a managed care entity unless the State has a contract that complies with specified requirements. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish uniform terminology for provider termination reasons in Medicaid by July 1, 2017. Increasing Availability of Medicaid Provider Information by requiring states to provide medical assistance on a fee-for-service basis and establish uniform terminology for provider termination reasons by July 1, 2017. The State requires providers to enroll and provide identifying information for individuals receiving medical assistance under the plan. Managed care providers must also enroll participating providers by January 1, 2018. Providers must enroll with the State agency administering the State plan by January 1, 2018, to participate in a managed care entity's network for individuals eligible for medical assistance. Enrollment requires providing identifying information such as name, specialty, date of birth, social security number, and license/certification numbers. Providers must enroll with the State agency by January 1, 2018, to participate in a managed care entity's network for individuals eligible for medical assistance. This does not require providers to offer services to individuals not enrolled with a managed care entity. Coordination with CHIP is also addressed in the Social Security Act. This requirement includes coordination with CHIP as outlined in the Social Security Act. Additionally, certain provider participation and payment limitations are specified in various sections of the Act. Section 1902(a)(39) of the Social Security Act is amended to exclude providers excluded from CHIP. The rule of construction ensures appeal rights of providers are not limited, and an OIG report is due by March 31, 2020. The OIG Report due by March 31, 2020, will assess the termination of providers under section 1902 of the Social Security Act from participation in State plans under title XIX and the Federal financial participation paid to States in violation of payment limitations.
